Topic.Title: Multiple models of Win 8 RT machines will run on faster Tegra 4

Message.Msg: If you can get Intel based versions of these PCs, with similar performance characteristics and broader software compatibility, why would anybody buy an RT machine? An ARM based version of Windows is going to be an even tougher sell with both AMD and Intel gunning for the fanless Windows 8 space. Tegra's best chance is to dominate the Android tablet/convertible market. There, I think that Nvidia can probably hold off Intel's incursion by really pushing Android gaming/Tegra Zone, as well as by broadly advertising the native Android apps that don't quite run well on Intel's chips. Should be interesting, but Windows RT is just pointless with Intel/AMD pushing into this space.

Message.Msg: AMD put a sock in it by tacking on 45% in 8 days didn't it? imho

Message.Title: "Microsoft admits customers don't understand Windows RT"
Message.Msg: "Microsoft needs to do a better job of explaining Windows RT to customers, especially considering the lack of backwards compatibility with apps, according to Windows vice-president Julie Larson-Green. The ARM-based version of Windows 8 doesn't have a standard desktop, leaving users with Windows 8 Store apps and the Start screen. As PC Pro has previously revealed, retailers haven't fully explained the difference between Windows RT and Windows 8 to customers - which isn't helping struggling Windows RT tablet sales." source: pcpro

Message.Title: The Good, Bad and UGLY
Message.Msg: Earnings Expectations: Analysts expect earnings of $0.10 per share on revenues of $940.60 million. Currently, the company’s P/E ratio stands at 15.34. The Good? Analysts have a more negative outlook for the company’s next-quarter performance. Over the past three months, the average estimate for next quarter’s earnings has fallen from a profit of $0.23 to a profit $0.14. The Bad. For the current year, the average estimate is a profit of $0.7, which is worse than the estimate ninety days ago. THE UGLY!

Topic.Title: Is this Nvidia board, or anti Apple board?

Message.Msg: I mostly buy stocks for the dividend but I have a few like Nvda that will likely power the future of the world. that's worth investing in. It happens to have a dividend now so even better than ever as far as I'm concerned. The company is cheap, if you add in cash and the value of its patents (I'm estimating $10-$15 a share) its trading at next to nothing. And Once the street realizes that Nvidia isn't just a computer company anymore its going up and staying up for a long time. Tegra 4i will likely finally get nvidia into smartphones in a decent way. may or may not effect stock price for another 3-9 months but once investors see it being a huge part of nvidia then stocks going to boom. Qualcom mentioned weakness due to competition. who do you think is that competition. nvidia, intel and some others. If you think about it. Cloud processing is the future. Grid is a big part of that. Nvidia doesn't have to be in the end device. they just power the processing of the image and sound else ware and stream it to your screen. so a game system may get a demo with no download or even the full game itself. It may send you the work that guy you hired to do a video or 3d model thing, shown in real time, allowing you to make changes quicker than ever. It provides for more immediate interaction. something that is incredibly valuable in today's business world. And Nvidia can charge a small fee for servicing the technology. another source of income and one that is very consistent. All AMD has going for it is they surprised everyone by not dieing with what may finally be a turn around. It will likely be like when Nvidia went to 26 on a short squeeze only to come back down again because it overshot. You claim Nvidia is a POS. what will you be calling AMD when it does the same thing. What will it take for Nvidia to prove itself to be something that you will no longer complain about.

Message.Title: "PS4 will not suffer major losses at launch 'unlike PS3,' says Sony"
Message.Msg: "ony does not foresee major losses being incurred at the launch of the PlayStation 4 later this year, unlike what was seen during the development and launch of the PlayStation 3, Sony CFO Masaru Kato said during an earnings call earlier today. "Unlike PS3, we are not planning a major loss to be incurred with the launch of PS4," said Kato. "At the time we developed PS3, we made a lot of in-house investments to develop the chip, the Cell chip," he explained. "Development of the chip saw the silicon processing and all the facilities invested by us ourselves. But this time, yes we have a team working on chip development, but we already have existing technology to incorporate and also product investment and all the facilities will now be invested by our partners, other foundries, so we don't have to make all the investment in-house." Sony's next-generation console will use semi-custom accelerated processing unit chips made by technology company AMD. These chips have been designed to allow developers to "easily harness the power of parallel processing to fundamentally change the console gaming experience," AMD's John Taylor said when the partnership with Sony was announced in February." Source : pologygon

Topic.Title: Is this Nvidia board, or anti Apple board?

Message.Msg: Investing in products and hiring when the economy was down helped a lot.. He saw the future in mobile and cloud and has shown that hes going to pursue that. I wouldn't want any less. The first report that includes grid sales is likely this quarter. looking forward to that. 4i is ahead of scheduled. That's Very Promising. Also they have been under promising lately. They have been beating estimates quarter after quarter. Stock price is the only thing that's not moving a lot. I'd say within 1 year nvidia will be higher than were we are now. and probably going much higher. It took Xbox several years to make a market for itself. Tegra is the same. Tegra 4i is the nearest term game changer here. Phones are high volume compared to tablets and cars and whatever else they are in. The regular Tegra 4 probably wont do much better than Tegra 3 did this last year. Grid has no baseline yet. and profits this quarter will probably be cruddy due to transition to next tegra. Guidance will be what sends this stock higher if it goes higher this quarter. But because they have had so many new initiatives lately that they don't have a baseline to guide off of yet. so they have been wishy washy so far. Is this the quarter where they guide more than a quarter or two or are we a quarter or two away from that? 10 cents a share is a low enough bar to get another beat on estimates. All that's left is guidance on what they see in the coming quarters now. We are also on the verge of next gen gaming. Theirs going to be lots of upgrades to graphics cards coming soon when people realize how much of a jump has happened between the last gen and this new one. the next Xbox could have something to do with grid... we will see soon enough. With AMD your cherry picking. Why not try predicting the next boom. hindsight is 20/20.

They trick is that they will have to be quite a bit cheaper, assuming that Intel and AMD produce x86 solutions that are as good as the claim. That might be tough, assuming that there are still plenty of Android opportunities out there they don't demand bargain-basement pricing.

Topic.Title: Bluestack rolls out a FREE Android Game Console

Message.Msg: Toys, games and luxury items are a very good business to be in, especially if you can hit the mass market while retaining a top brand name. Someone that buys a truck for only work gets a low-margin basic model that gets the job done. When they buy one for fun, they typically spend a little over twice as much and replace it much sooner. Which is far more profitable for the maker. The same is true for computers. The lesson I take away from Bluestacks is told in the reviews: we are on the verge of cloud gaming becoming becoming usable, but we need another step in compute power and lower latency. Nvidia is working both sides of that problems, with GPU-focused mobile compute chips and having the unique opportunity to reduce the latency at the video encoding point.

Message.Title: Barrons on NVIDIA Q1 FY2014 financial results (before the conference call)
Message.Msg: By Tiernan Ray Chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) this afternoon reported fiscal Q1 revenue and earnings per share that topped analysts’ estimates. Revenue in the three months ended in March fell 13.7%, year over year, to $954.7 million, yielding EPS of 18 cents. Analysts had been modeling $941 million and 10 cents per share. Nvidia shares are up 44 cents, or almost 3%, at $14.35, in late trading. Nvidia said it repurchased $100 million worth of shares in the quarter, and paid out $46.3 million in dividends. Nvidia’s “GPU” computing division saw sales rise 8%, year over year, and fall 5.6% from Q4′s level, to $785.6 million. Sales in the “Tegra” line of mobile application processors fell 22%, year over year, and fell 50.5%, quarter to quarter, to $103.1 million. Gross margin, on a non-GAAP basis, rose to 54.6% from 50.4% in the year-earlier quarter, and 53.2% in the prior quarter. Nvidia’s CEO, Jen-Hsun Huang, remarked that “The success of Kepler-based GPUs within and beyond the PC helped drive another quarter of record margins,” adding that “Kepler is capturing share among gamers, strengthening our workstation and supercomputing segments, and will fuel new growth opportunities for our GRID server graphics solutions.” ______ PS: Tegra business did a lot better than I thought, considering that Q1 is essential a dry period during which multiple product transitions took place.

Message.Title: Some key points from the earnings conference
Message.Msg: --Icera500 (4G, LTE modem) and T4i certifications continue to be on track. Expected in Q2 and Q3 respectively. The phone market (tablet also) that T4i serves represents THE SWEET SPOT in the telcom space: large size and fastest growing. --More than 100 potential customers for the upcoming GRID VCA appliance. Approximately launch date Q3 --NVIDIA's yet to be launched Project Shield could be the biggest surprise of all. Clearly the official financial guidance provided by NV has not included the benefits of this wild card. --Current quarter (Q2 FY2014) will see revenue increased to $975 milllion, from $954 of Q1 while maintaining a high gross margin of 54.6% --Kepler/GPU ecosystem continues to expand significantly - feeding into gamers market, servers, workstations and supercomputing.

Message.Title: WSJ; NVIDIA Q1 profit rises 29% as revenue, gross margin strengthen (VERY POSITIVE COMMENTSRY!)
Message.Msg: Nvidia Corp.'s (NVDA) fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 29% as the chip maker posted stronger revenue and margins. For the current quarter, the company forecast revenue of $975 million, plus or minus 2%, implying a range of between $955.5 million and $994.5 million. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters most recently expected $1.01 billion. The Santa Clara, Calif., company is best known for making chips and circuit boards that help computers and videogame consoles generate visual effects. Over the years, the company has expanded into making chips for mobile devices, boosting its sales as companies such as Google Inc. (GOOG) and Microsoft Corp. (MSFT) use its chips in their tablets. President and Chief Executive Jen-Hsun Huang said Thursday the company's Kepler-based graphics processing units--or GPUs--drove record margins. "Kepler is capturing share among gamers, strengthening our workstation and supercomputing segments, and will fuel new growth opportunities for our GRID server graphics solutions," Mr. Huang said. "With Tegra 4 devices and Tegra 4i certification on the way, we're gearing up to return to growth in the second half." For the quarter ended April 28, Nvidia reported a profit of $77.9 million, or 13 cents a share, up from $60.4 million, or 10 cents a share, a year earlier. Excluding stock-based compensation, acquisition-related impacts and other items, adjusted earnings were up at 18 cents from 16 cents a share. Analysts most recently forecast 10 cents a share. Revenue increased 3.2% to $954.7 million. The company in February projected roughly $940 million, well below analysts' revenue expectations at the time. onlineDOTwsjDOTcom/article/BT-CO-20130509-717114.html?mod=WSJ_qtoverview_wsjlatest
